questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with complaints of vomiting and diarrhoea along with skin eruptions. He gives the history of similar episodes in the past. After switching to gluten free diet his symptoms resolved. Which marker is useful in diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Anti tissue transglutaminase antibody

The given scenario of vomiting, diarrhoea, skin eruptions and resolving symptoms with gluten free diet along with crypt hperplasia, villous atrophy and intra epithelial lymphocyte as seen in histopathology are suggestive of celiac disease. Anti tissue transglutaminase antibody will help in diagnosing this condition.

questions.text: A patient presented with a painless, well-circumscribed swelling near the wrist joint. There are no skin changes or neurological involvement. Histopathological examination of the swelling revealed spindle cells with palisading of the nuclei as shown in the image below. Which of the following is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Verocay bodies

The given clinical scenario of a painless, well-circumscribed swelling near the wrist joint along with the nuclear-free zones between nuclear palisading observed in the given image is suggestive of schwannoma. Verocay bodies are seen in this condition.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of a palpable mass in both breasts. Histopathology examination shows the following finding. Immunohistochemistry showed estrogen receptor positivity. Which protein that maintains cell adhesion, and thereby inhibits cell motility, is mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

E Cadherin
The given scenario is suggestive of lobular carcinoma of the breast which involves mutated E-cadherin protein. In this condition, the histopathological examination shows infiltrating small monomorphic discohesive tumor cells arranged in an Indian-file or single-file pattern.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease 

The patient's presentation of diabetic retinopathy with proteinuria and the histopathological image showing acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules with increased mesangial matrix is highly suggestive of Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents with complaints of facial puffiness and frothy urine. The given histology image shows the presence of membranous nephropathy. Which of the following statements are false regarding it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Sub-endothelial deposits

Membranous nephropathy is characterised by diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall due to the deposition of IgG and C3 along the sub- epithelial side of the basement membrane. The image is characteristic of membranous nephropathy. The given hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained image shows uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall. (intense pink color).

questions.text: A middle-aged man with emphysema was found to have elevated liver transaminases. His liver biopsy image is given below. These inclusions are periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant. Which type of emphysema does this patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Panacinar emphysema

The presence of PAS-positive and diastase- resistant inclusion bodies in the hepatocytes is suggestive of a1 antitrypsin deficiency. This condition is associated with panacinar type of emphysema.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented with a 3-week history of yellow skin and sclerae but is otherwise asymptomatic. There is a history of similar episodes 2 years back. Occasionally, he has noticed dark-colored urine. Serum bilirubin-4.4 mg/dL (Predominantly conjugated), Serum AST, ALT- Normal. A liver biopsy, stained with Fontana-Masson stain is shown in the image below. Which of the following Is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Dubin-Johnson syndrome

The clinical features and the liver biopsy showing characteristic deposition of black-colored pigment is suggestive of Dubin-Johnson syndrome.
Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and conspicuous brown-black melanin- like pigment deposition in the liver. The disease is caused due to mutation in multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP-2) in hepatocytes, which is required for the transport of non-bile salt organic anions at the canalicular membranes.

choices.text: Testing spheroidal red cell in spherocytosis
Red cell lysis for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria

questions.text: An infant presented with anemia. A blood test was performed where 0.36% saline was added to the blood sample. The control and test results are shown below. What is this test used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Screening of thalassemia

The given image shows NESTROFT i.e. Naked eye single tube red cell osmotic fragility test. It is a very useful screening tool for thalassemia, particularly in poor resource settings.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female has a firm neck swelling and dysphagia for 3 months. Blood tests show elevated calcitonin levels, and she has a family history of similar issues. A biopsy is performed for diagnosis. What mutation is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

RET

The patient is suffering from medullary thyroid carcinoma. RET mutation is associated with this condition. The points that favor the diagnosis are the age of the patient, the presence of neck swelling, elevated calcitonin levels, positive family history, and histopathology image showing the presence of amyloid-rich stroma.

questions.text: A patient presented with the development of seizures for which the CT guided biopsy was done. The histopathology report shows the presence of psammoma bodies as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Meningioma

Psammoma bodies (PBs) are concentric lamellated calcified structures, observed most commonly in papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC), meningioma, and papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma of ovary. The presence of seizures indicates the disease relation with the brain.

choices.text: Increased growth of capillary endothelial cells

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a painless lesion on her right ear lobe as shown in the image below. She reports that her ears were pierced 4 months ago. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of this lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Excessive production of extracellular matrix

Keloid is an exuberant scar that tends to progress beyond the site of the initial injury and recurs after excision.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man has increasing fatigue, with lab results showing serum creatinine at 4.7 mg/dL and urea nitrogen at 44 mg/dL. An abdominal ultrasound reveals symmetrically smaller kidneys. The high-magnification microscopic appearance indicates which underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Systemic hypertension

The figure shows an arteriole with marked hyaline thickening, indicating hyaline arteriolosclerosis, often seen in diabetic kidneys. Sepsis may cause arteriolar hyaline thrombi due to disseminated intravascular coagulation. Cancer-related debilitation usually reduces vascular disease from atherosclerosis. Syphilis can lead to vasculitis affecting the aorta's vasa vasorum, while polyarteritis affects large to medium-sized arteries in various organs, including the kidneys, showing fibrinoid necrosis and wall inflammation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman gives birth to a term infant after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. The infant is cyanotic at birth. Two months later, physical examination shows the infant to be at the 37th percentile for height and weight. The representative gross appearance of the infant's heart is shown in the figure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Transposition of the great vessels 

The figure shows the aorta emerging from the right ventricle and the pulmonic trunk from the left, indicating complete transposition of the great vessels, which is incompatible with life unless there are connections like a ventricular septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus, or patent foramen ovale. In aortic or pulmonic stenosis, the great arteries are small but normally positioned. Tetralogy of Fallot features an overriding aorta without transposition, while truncus arteriosus results from improper development of the spiral septum.

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient with a long-standing history of rheumatic heart disease was admitted to hospital due to severe breathlessness. She died on the 3rd day following admission. The mitral valve shows the following findings on autopsy. What is the cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Calcification and fibrosis

The given image is of mitral stenosis showing fish mouth or buttonhole appearance in rheumatic heart disease. It is due to calcification and fibrosis.

questions.text: A patient presents with midline swelling in the neck. Biopsy revealing Orphan Annie eye nuclei is shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Papillary carcinoma

The presence of empty appearing nuclei, also called Orphan Annie eye nuclei as seen in the above image is diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with a retroperitoneal mass. Biopsy from the lesion is shown in the image below. Molecular analysis revealed t(12:16). What is the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Myxoid Liposarcoma

Myxoid liposarcoma is characterized by abundant ground substance, branching capillaries, and scattered immature adipocytes. It's the second most common sarcoma in adults, typically occurring in the 5th to 6th decades, often in deep soft tissues of the extremities or retroperitoneum. 
Liposarcomas have three histological subtypes:

1. Well-differentiated: Mature adipocytes and spindle cells; associated with 12q13-15 amplification.

2. Myxoid: Abundant basophilic matrix with branching capillaries and few immature adipocytes; linked to t(12:16).

3. Pleomorphic: Anaplastic cells with bizarre nuclei; most malignant.

Pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most aggressive, while well-differentiated is the least. Myxoid liposarcoma has intermediate malignancy.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presented with a history of fatigue and tiredness. On investigation, he was found to have Hb = 9 gm% and MCV =101 FL. Peripheral smear examination showed macrocytic RBC and hypersegmented neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)  

Chronic alcoholism

The given findings are suggestive of macrocytic anaemia, which can be seen in chronic alcoholics. Anemic patients with a peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hypersegmented neutrophils are important characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Juvenile polyp

The clinical features and the histopathological image showing characteristic cystically dilated crypts and glands are suggestive of a juvenile polyp. Juvenile polyps are malformations of epithelium and lamina propria commonly located in the rectum. It is seen in children <5 years of age. The typical presentation is painless rectal bleeding. Sometimes there may be a proliferating rectal mass.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of her breast. Histopathological examination of the mass showed cells in mucin pools and faint nuclei. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Colloid carcinoma

The given scenario is suggestive of colloid or mucinous carcinoma of the breast.
Colloid carcinoma is an invasive breast carcinoma, which shows intracellular and extracellular mucin deposition. On histopathological examination, extracellular type shows tumor cells with faint nuclei, arranged in clusters, floating in lakes or pools of mucin. In intracellular type, nuclei are pushed to the periphery to form a signet ring appearance.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a long history of dyspnea, chronic cough with sputum, and wheezing died of respiratory failure following a bout of lobar pneumonia. She was not a smoker or an alcoholic. The lung at autopsy is shown in the image below. Which of the following is most likely to cause the pathological changes shown?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency

The above gross specimen shows emphysematous damage involving enlargement of the entire acinus suggestive of panacinar emphysema. It is caused due to alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency. In panacinar (panlobular) emphysema, the acini are uniformly enlarged from the level of the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli. It occurs commonly in the lower zones and in the anterior margins of the lung and is most severe at the bases.
The image below shows panacinar emphysema.
